39295182.review:
tl;dr: Highly recommended for the first 10-15 hours, recommended with some qualifications for the rest of the play-time.  

Root Double begins by giving you a choice between two routes. The default choice is route A(fter), which starts you off in the middle of a dangerous situation and gives you a good dozen hours of intense (for a VN) drama. You watch from the perspective of Watase, a rescue worker, as he and his fellow survivors struggle to escape a catastrophic laboratory accident. This route feels tailored to players who prefer action/horror VNs; its bad ends are violent, plentiful, and sometimes difficult to see coming, and there's a sense of distrust and paranoia among the cast. The other choice is route B(efore), which gives you the lead-up to, and early hours of, this accident from the perspective of Natsuhiko: a teen boy who spends his days with his gaggle of lady friends but who suddenly finds himself responsible for averting a disaster. Route B seems like it would appeal more to people who enjoy slice-of-life and romance VNs; its pace is slower, with fewer choices and relatively predictable outcomes, and while the events of route A loom in the future, this route devotes a lot of time to its protagonist's everyday life and childhood memories.

There's a reason why Root Double's action is split between two (often overlapping) perspectives: one of the game's major messages is that empathy is a vital human characteristic, and that our well-being depends on our ability to consider situations from other people's perspectives. At the same time, the perspective split is kind of poorly implemented. I have no idea why the developers decided to let you choose between the routes, because that element of choice seems just to have made the pacing of this VN a bit of a mess. Starting with B means that you'll benefit from a gradual ramp-up of the action and a much more straightforward approach to the decision-making system, but you're also thrown into a sometimes painfully generic romance VN situation (complete with branches that depend on saying the right thing to your lady companions). Route B also straight-up spoils many of route A's twists and carefully-paced revelations. Starting with A, meanwhile, is what I'd recommend, but doing so means that you'll finish reading that route feeling excited to learn what's going on, but then you'll spend another dozen or so hours reading a story about a bunch of goofy anime teens. The poor pacing of route B is all the more noticeable after route A, especially because B forces you to scroll through long-winded and repetitive explanations of the game's sci-fi concepts after route A has already given you an adequate understanding of them. The game's subsequent routes--which are unlocked after you finish A and B--clear up all of the mysteries established in the earlier ones, but they also suffer from a similar sense of repetitiveness. I hope you like examining the same books and reading the same pieces of dialogue and watching the same events play out multiple times with slight variations...

Endings in this game are reached through the choices you make using the "Senses Sympathy" decision-making system.  At first, this system feels unnecessarily obtuse: choices that are often simple binaries are made using sliders that represent each of the 9 major characters. Deciding to pair up with character y, for instance, means setting their slider higher than that of character x at a branching point; trusting character z means setting their slider to the highest value.  The slider for your viewpoint character is a little more complicated, especially in route A, because its meaning can change depending on the context.  Setting it low or high can indicate (to give a few examples) whether you defer to someone else's judgement or go with your own, meekly accept criticism or stand up for yourself, question your abilities or feel confident in them, or refuse to pay attention or remain alert. The issue is that it's not always clear which of these possibilities is the relevant one in a given scene, which can lead to some frustrating bad ends when your protagonist acts in an unexpected way. The good news is that the game auto-saves at every decision point and, if you leave them turned on, the tips that appear after bad ends will usually give you a clear indication as to how you can achieve a better outcome. Initially, I found this system frustrating, but as the story went on and its plot relevance became clearer, I came to appreciate it. In the end, I think its thematic value outweighs its occasional moments of clunkiness.
  
I don't have much to say about the art and music in Root Double: they exist and are inoffensive. The backgrounds are serviceable but the game's primary setting (a big lab filled with interconnected rooms and staircases, all with mostly identical designs) conveniently allows for a lot of re-use of assets. The character portraits are expressive enough, but the style in which the female characters are drawn, in particular, sometimes feels a little too cute for the intense situations these characters are dropped into. The music is always well-suited to the situation, but the soundtrack suffers a little from a lack of variety: you'll hear almost every track in the game early on in your playthrough. Nothing is grating in this production, but nothing really stands out, either.

If it seems as though I'm lukewarm on Root Double, it's probably because this is a good game with an even better one hiding under a mountain of text that's very well-localized but which could have used some more editing. If you're familiar with and enjoy Takumi Nakazawa's VNs (or you're into other games, like the Zero Escape series, that share some of those games' DNA), you'll know what to expect here, and you'll almost certainly like it. It just isn't likely to be something that sticks with you in the way that the great games of this genre do.

38922271.review:
***While I DO recommend this game, it is a weak thumbs up. There are issues. See below for details.***

Root Double is a visual novel in the style of the classic Ever17, with some similarities to works like Steins;Gate or 999: Nine Hours, Nice Persons, Nine Doors. At its core its a classic thriller scenario: Some people are trapped and are likely to die unless they find their way out. But like the aforementioned VNs, its heart and soul is in both the heavy science-fiction elements of its plot and the writing of character relationships. If you've read or played some of those, you know roughly what to expect: A fun and suspenseful story that reveals its layers to you over time, until suddenly you're hip deep in mind-blowing sci-fi mechanics and hidden motives and terrible truths. Its great fun! 

Unfortunately, Root Double is a slow burner. There is a LOT of exposition. And while its complex science-fiction ideas do merit more exposition than usual, this VN really just gets bogged down. Explanations last far longer than necessary for the viewer to understand things, and they're repeated, sometimes quite frequently, as you play the different routes. 

The way the player makes decisions is also needlessly obfuscated with a complex system involving gradations of "positive feelings" that the protagonists have towards other people. In many cases, it can be hard to tell what a particular level of positivity even indicates. In some situations the protagonist will agree with a character, in others they'll disagree with them because they want to protect them, in yet others seemingly nothing will happen at all. Its confusing and kinda pointless.

I found the characters fairly hit or miss. Some feel like 90s anime stereotypes whose voice acting grates painfully against your skull. Others are reasonably intriguing, even endearing. None of them are fantastic sadly, and the portrayal of female characters errs towards patronizing (what should be powerful and capable female characters are sidelined in various ways to let the male heroes lead the way). But if you do like them, you'll love the sheer depth given to how their backstories all interweave in interesting ways.

The plot itself is fairly good. Route A is suspenseful and intriguing. Route B is dull, but somehow servicably manages to get you to care about a new set of characters. The remaining routes unlocked after those two are really interesting (though sometimes so heavy on exposition that they feel like they overstay their welcome), and the twists, while more predictable than I'd like, were satisfying. It does suffer from moralizing a particular point of view that (I suspect) resonates worse with western audiences than it did with the original Japanese one. [spoiler]Characters whose goals were to defeat a heinous evil organization (LABO) are portrayed as misguided or even evil, simply because their plan was against the law and could have resulted in casualties among LABOs staff. Even though their plan took an absurd degree of care to avoid casualties.[/spoiler] 

Overall, decent. It never reaches the mindblowing emotional heights of Steins;Gate or 999, and it feels like a bit of a retread of Ever17, but it still manages to stand on its own as an exciting story.

38440218.review:
Length : About 65 hours

So, as stated just above, it's a very long VN. And it's fully voiced by talented people.
The overall quality is very good and the music was nice too. 
While reading it, the setting and the ambience kinda reminded me of Ever 17. With more fire and less water.

The story is an adventure/mystery kind and it's separated into four sections plus a bonus one (√After, √Before, √Current, √Double and Extend Episode). Only two episodes are available at first, and the others get unlocked one by one once you finish those. 

I began with √After first, then jumped to √Before but I'm not sure I would forcefully recommend on doing the same. 
Let me explain :

√After is an adventure-mystery story following a rescue worker named Kasasagi Watase who's dispatched on a disaster scene and suffers a loss of memory due to some event. You more or less begin the game just after that and thus go into the story while being completely blind, both the protagonist and you the reader.

√Before on the other hand is slice of life-ish and shows the days before the disaster from the point of view of Tenkawa Natsuhiko, a high-schooler, and his close friends. It's slow and peaceful compared to √After and introduces the characters from the other group of survivors whom you don't really meet during the first episode.

So, reading √After, then √Before is the intended order [b]but[/b] the very nature of √Before slows down greatly the rythm of the story and can make the reading a bit painful after the fast-paced non-stop action of the last part of √After that ends on a cliffhanger. And also, since √Before is all about people you know nothing about since you only got a glimpse of them during √After, you're not compelled to know about them at this point. 

On the other hand, going √Before -> √After [b]would spoil[/b] lots of things in √After, plus making the amnesia gimmick lose its shine since it would be reduced to a plot point rather than a way to introduce the reader into the story [b]but[/b] would make the pacing of the story a whole lot better and painless.

So I still recommend the order in which it's presented to you but it can be a hurdle for some people; I think I'm an avid reader but even for me, it took me multiple sessions to go through √Before. I couldn't read it in just two sessions like I did for √After. Really, that's the greatest negative point of this VN.

After that, you get the √Current episode. Then the √Double. It's hard to talk about them without spoilers but to summarize, √Current is the joint adventure of Kasasagi and Tenkawa (it's a bit on the short side) and √Double is the second half of the game, with all the revelations, climaxes and endings where everything comes together.

On a side note, it took me 44 hours to reach what felt like the real opening.

What about the Extend Episode ? It's a bonus containing some recaps of things you already read, with additionnal scenes. It's unlocked after witnessing the true ending and it's also the very last piece of the puzzle. 

So, do I recommend it ? Yes. Very much so.

37296290.review:
If you're familiar with the Takumi Nakazawa's work (specifically the Infinity series), you will get a feeling of familiarity as this visual novel follows similar themes in his previous works. Even so, this is definitely a thrilling experience for fans that are already accustomed to the genre. If you haven't read his other sci-fi visual novels, do it if you like this one.

This game starts with two routes: A and B. A is faster paced than B, but it leaves far more questions than answers. If you start A first, you will be thrown into a confused chaos, all cleverly planned of course. B is a slow slice of life that has intermittent action sequences. It is enjoyable and you will get more answers, but it is really slow. It made me feel like reading less per day as a result. I was willing to ignore the flaws of the slow route because the final routes that were unlocked were worth the wait.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who likes sci-fi's with decent twists to them. As a fair warning, this visual novel is absolutely massive. Make sure you have the time to dedicate reading something this gigantic. I unlocked everything in the game (TIPS, endings, CG, etc.) in 128 hours, but the normal reading time is probably between 40-60 hours. I bought it on sale for 50% off, but it is worth the full price if a sale price isn't available. Anything less than 50% off is a steal.

36639243.review:
I know why you're here. 

You're here because you heard that this was the brainchild of Takumi Nakazawa, one of the masterminds behind the Infinity series. You know that this particular name being in the credits can only mean one thing: you're gonna sh*t some bricks. 

And bricks you shall sh*t, because just like the Infinity works, this game is a "trapped" mystery/thriller with some big, surprising plot twists. Now, is the writing in this game as good as its predecessors? I'd say no: the core concept is great, but the scenarios themselves are rather average. The science-fiction this time around is rather weak as well: there may come a point in time when you will ask yourself when exactly the "science" part of "sci-fi" departed the story and left you with just "fiction", the contrived kind that serves simply to conveniently advance the plot.

The art and sound aren't anything to write home about. I'm not a fan of the character art style nor the backgrounds. The usage and quality of the sound effects are poor in general, and the BGM is mediocre at best. However the voice acting is quite good; Megumi Toyoguchi and Akane Tomonaga, both of whom had roles in Remember11, lend a hand here. The former reprises her role as the b*tchy young professional, while the latter smashes the role of the fang-flashing genki girl.

Is Root Double as well written, concise, or memorable as its predecessors? No. Is it a good spiritual successor to the Infinity series? Yes, and it's worth checking out.

36177617.review:
What is a Visual Novel? Some people (for example: me) see VN more like interactive books or something closer to interactive theater rather than video game. It’s popular in Japan and slowly getting popularity from western audience. What it might be surprising for some people is pricing of games like this. Pricing of top VN might be close to AAA titles what could surprise players unfamiliar  with this genre. If you never played/read VN before I can assure you that this title is good place to start. Just make sure that you start playing [b][u]Root After[/u][/b] first. Root Before answers some of the questions in Root After at the very beginning and you want to avoid that.

Root Double -Before Crime * After Days was the VN title that surprised me the most (in positive way, of course)At this moment it holds 3rd place in my VN ranking together with Ever17. To be honest, in my opinion this title should be little higher in VNDB ranking. 

When you start the game you are waking up into world in year 2030 at LABO, a giant scientific research facility built by a lake on the outskirts of Rokumei City where an incident occurs. In result you are trapped inside this facility and You will be facing lots of dangers. You will be playing as Watase Kasagi an amnesiac rescue captain and you have to survive during lockdown. After clearing this route you will play as Natsuhiko Tenkawa as he goes through incidents as well as his life the week before we get to know more about this future world and why certain things are happening inside the LABO. 

Story itself is well-written, there are interesting twists, developing characters, lots of endings - 39 (bad, normal, good) with impressively executed final route. This VN could read even someone who is not interested in that kind of games. I even think that RD makes a great first VN.

At the beginning I explained more or less how VN looks like and what is unique in Root Double that there is no “answers” which players select. Instead you will be using Senses Sympathy System (SSS). During the gameplay you will have to make a choice how much you trust each character and this choice will affect the direction of the game.

The visual production value of Root Double is top-quality. Sprites, CGs and backgrounds all look great and visual effects are put to good use frequently. Music is also good quality but it lacks some memorable tracks.

Very few productions feature the number of intriguing mysteries and revelations hidden within its depths and it takes the time to get them all but I found that time definitely worth it

Pros:
[list]
[*]Great story for anybody,
[*]Interesting characters that develop during the game,
[*]Well-designed art (Sprites, CGs and background),
[*]Multiple endings with great executed final route,
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]SSS is unique but may confuse players.
[/list]

36052328.review:
This one is a pretty high quality mystery novel that opens up and transforms piece by piece as you progress in the story.

Do note that this is both character building/interaction- and exposition-heavy story. Writer does admirable attempt at fleshing out the world and characters and the way it differs from our own. You will either like this approach or not. For me it was fine for most part. YMMV, you've been warned.

Novel is divided in five parts, of which only two are open for reading initially (After, Before, Current, Double and Xtend). Play completely through episode "After" first, even though logically and chronologically it would seem better to read "Before" first. It's not, just trust me on this.

Voice acting is one of the highlights here, as it is both high quality and all dialogue is voiced. This is also a pretty long story, so as long as you like the subject matter you will get your "money's worth" for sure. I'd say you'll spend at least 50 hours if you actually listen the dialogue. I'd say it took about 65 to get through the main stuff and then few more hours poking around for different endings and Xtend extras.

I recommend this VN for any fan of light science fiction and mystery stories.

35608763.review:
For those unfamiliar, visual novels are, true to their name, a crossbreed of novels and a visual medium. Think of it as a play with still pictures instead of actors: characters have dialogues, monologues, and non-verbal interactions between each other, all depicted with anime styled drawings, full voice acting, sound effects, and background music. It is a popular medium in Japan and is slowly getting more popular in the west. 

Root Double is an exceptional visual novel. At a research institude dubbed the Laboratory of Atomic and Biological Organization (LABO for short), multiple explosions occured, leading to a mass evacuation while a research team rushes in. Shortly, a lockdown order was issued in the fear of a nuclear meltdown while nine lives remain trapped inside. Dead bodies with gunshot wounds, people who shouldn't be there, there seems to be a lot of mystery surrounding the LABO explosions and lockdown, and it's one of the things that drew me in. 

I felt Root Double is about 60% sci-fi and 40% mystery. While it could be seen as a closed circle who-dun-it, it's better to not treat it as such. The mystery is more about circumstances of each character and how they reached LABO, rather than how the dead bodies came about. Everything is well foreshadowed, which contributes to the best part of Root Double: its writing. The other big piece of its excellent writing is its world building (with believable "science" rules), which attributes to the sci-fi nature of this visual novel. 

While writing, voice acting, art, and music is all excellent, pacing issues prevents it from getting a perfect 10. Many flashbacks at key moments disrupt the flow of the story, and some flashblacks are simply too long, clumped together, and are too similar. 

Still, Root Double has made its way to my top 5 visual novels in terms of writing, and it comes highly recommended.

I have to say im pretty new to the Visual Novel Genre but Root Double rly gave me a blast.
You play it for the first time and think: "Hey that is a pretty cool setting, a lot of interesting stuff happens and since you can decide how much you 'trust' others  (or even yourself) you can influence the story in whole" After hell a lot of play time you land in a some kind dissatisfying ending, but nevertheless enjoyed your time trying things and even achieving a lot of things. First time I didnt even see half of the important chars, then I saw them and understood their connections, afterwards it comes out that they had even deeper connections then you thought they would have and so its a really joyful ride to find everything out this game has to offer.

The only bad about it is, that i repeats itself many times.....more precisely i mean this: (Keeping in mind you can always skip scenes you have already read up to that point where you havent) You play a scene with one unimportant decision, then, second try, you make the other decision. 34868220.review:
Root Double -Before Crime * After Days is definitely one the best VNs on steam. [i]At least if you are interested in story.[/i] Relatively setting, I think, I shouldn't repeat description entirely, but try to remark the merits instead.
The plot is narrated through several (mostly the featured two) protagonists, revealing it from multiple angles, that are good at supplementing each other if you read the roots at alphabetic sequence. Not all of them are equally good, moreover some are written supplemental intentionally. Story isn't complicated enough to dumbfound reader completely, but it manages to keep tension and intrigue well. Lots of details come in engrossing rate together as parts of exciting aggregation.

Without spoilers I could say, that SF part is rather hard and thorough. Especially the first chapter is laden with plethora of such details, for multiple facts even an ingame encyclopedia is given. Also in game's setting [spoiler]telepathy[/spoiler] somehow resembles Rifters trilogy without marine attributes. 
Someones might disagree, but I'd like to say that featured SSSystem, which around gameplay is built, is good at making choise input more subtle, than ordinary line picking (but also can complicate branching).

Visual style is typical for mikeou and is rather unexpected to be found in non moe vn. Contribution of lip animations is substantial. In addition to them, sound is just perfect, voice acting of each character grasps after half a dozen phrases and represents it's owner individually. Accordingly, all characters are written to have personal speech habits and even with sound-off many lines are good at representing situation and mood. Moreover, disclosure of characters' individuality and their past, which define the story, provides reader with at least half of overall experience.

As a bad trait I could touch multiple narrative approach toward the same situations, that protracts seriously (esp. the extra episode, half of which can be easily put down), although, it also helps to memorize the story (or at least current chapter) wholly and, since the skip option is present, it's not significant in repeated reading.
Considering the plot, majority of bad endings aren't important, but they end up with narrative impasse quickly after wrong choises, hereby this flaw could be considered as just a method to create atmosphere of danger. Besides, some plotholes are represented [spoiler](Like Kazami not using corpses in one of normal D endings)[/spoiler], but in compare to overall volume of text and routes their number is small.

It's a VN that shows you don't need to have to have R18 content in it for it to be enjoyable.  I've had quite a few sleepless nights playing through the game, especially during Routes A, C and D.  You take control of 2 characters throughout the story.  Kasasagi Watase is the main character of Route A.  He is a Rescue Worker called in to save the workers of LABO after several explosions threaten a nuclear meltdown.  The other character you control is Tenkawa Natsuhiko who is a school student, Communicator, and that gets trapped in LABO during the incident.

It's highly recommended you play through Route A first since you have access to both A and B are the start even though Route A takes places after Route B chronologically.  Route A has lots of action and choices involved to keep everything interesting.  You will root for certain characters, then hope they die, then root for them again.  Go into the game without trying to disect the plot and predict what happens.  There are certain parts where it's easy to do this, but I feel it's better if you don't.

Route B is the "Backstory" or "Before Crime" route.  It takes place about a week before Route A and gives a lot of insight into the powers that Communicators have.  It drags on a bit in certain spots which can put a damper on the pacing when comparing it to Route A.  Power through it because the last couple chapters of Route B make up for it a lot.

Route C is a recap of Route A in the perspective of both characters.

Route D takes place after Route A, also in the perspective of both characters as they work together to escape LABO and not die in the process.  

It's a fantastic VN that I feel does not disappoint.  The only bad part was the slog of Route B, but it's necessary to learn about Communicators and more about the city they live in.  It has a fair amount of twists and turns and knows how to keep things interesting.  There are definitely a lot of sh*t VNs out there, but this is one I can easily recommend.  I don't usually play VNs if they aren't over 30 hours because I "like to get my moneys worth".  This game can easily take you 50 hours to play through.  Very enjoyable and worth playing through.

34071354.review:
Well this game took me by surprise. How to explain Root Double...

Root Double is a thriller/drama about a fictional event in a research facility that went completely awry on September 16th 2030. You initially view the events unfolding through the eyes of Watase, currently an amnesiac, who must slowly piece together what is going on and how to escape from a nightmare of fire and radioactivity. There is no 18+ patch and no sexual content, but there is a fair amount of violence, so be warned.

The story is told through the perspectives of multiple different characters, and there is no singular protagonist. Furthermore, the story departs a little bit from traditional choice-based visual novels; you may control the story and its outcome, but you do so through an odd system, the Sense system. The Sense sysem will activate whenever a special moment happens in the story, allowing you to control the character's sense of confidence in others, including themselves. One you have set their 'Sense', the story will proceed, and they will make a decision based on what their Sense level is. In order to control the decisions of the character, you must toy with the Sense menu, instilling extra faith in anyone who seems to have a good idea worth following - many times, it is correct to lower your own character's confidence in themselves to prevent them from being brash and getting themselves killed.

AND OH BOY DO THEY GET KILLED. If you don't like blood and violence in your writing (electronic or otherwise), stay away from Root Double. This isn't a 'romance' VN full of cat girls and bath scenes, this VN's a bloody drama-turned-tragedy. When you're trying to figure how to lead the characters through this horrible mess of panic and terror as you try to avoid radioactive death.

The confusion is part of the fun though. The writing in Root Double is very thorough, with everything shockingly thought out from start to finish. If something happens and you don't understand why, it's because you don't have the full picture yet. However, the further you progress, the more pieces you have to put together, and the story slowly begins to make sense. If you really start to get into the story, you might even begin to start figuring out things on your own before the story spells it out, and figuring out the mystery that is LABO.

One criticism I do have with the story is its tendency to replay scenes. Since you will be viewing the story from the perspective of multiple characters, there is overlap where things get re-explained, and the action slows down. If you're invested, this won't be a problem, but some might be put off by the tendency for the story's tendency to retell the same events from a different character's perspective again and again. It -is- critical to understanding the story, and it does show just how thorough the authors were in contructing the story piece by piece to make sure no plothole was left unplugged, but I can say it can distract from getting to the meat of the story. Otherwise, the world building is spot on - the story is consistent, but explains itself bit by bit, and the supernatural elements aren't dumped on you right at the start, giving you time to learn and understand them as they are progressively introduced.

What is fantastic however is the depth and breadth of each character. They all have their own reasons for having ended up where they are, whether they intended to or not. The story plays on the themes of minds and memories, and each character's past outlines their motives and purpose for being there on the day of the accident, from their boring every day lives to the present conflict.

How to actually enjoy Root Double is up to you. I found that Root Double's tendency to retell its stories from different perspectives combined with its sheer length made it more pleasant to read in small bits, rather than trying to chomp down on an entire arc in one sitting. Many stories are better read in a short span of time so that you don't start forgetting bits of the story, but this doesn't hold true for Root Double which is better to read over a longer course of time. It's also not incorrect to read this using a walkthrough; there are some spoiler-light walkthroughs that tell you how to get to an ending without telling you exactly what happens, and this is one VN where I wouldn't consider it totally wrong to use a walkthrough. However, even with these it can still take 35+ hours to get through to the end, so consider Root Double to be equal to a full-length novel where you'll have to stick a bookmark in periodically.

Is it worth reading? Yes, though the VN's complexity and mature themes lends itself to a higher age group than your standard run-of-the-mill VN. Root Double does have a 'tip' section for explaining non-fictional terminology like what a milli-Sievert is or why Charles Bonnet Syndrome is different from other hallucination-inducing mental illnesses, but an appreciation for science may help with one's enjoyment of the story overall.

I recommend this VN for anyone who's looking for something a little more intense and a little more heartwrenching than your usual run-of-the-mill VN.

33424565.review:
Completing this game 100% should take maybe 40 hours, and choosing options to only reach the true end should take maybe around 20 hours.

I've finished all 4 episodes but haven't got to finishing the bad ends. My favorite route by far was Root A, which I recommend everyone starts with since it allows Root B to serve as a better exposition to the later two routes, Root C and Root D. 

There are a lot of flashbacks throughout every section, which serve to help your recall abilities. This made the game easier to play in multiple settings as opposed to other VNs which many people should be thankful for. On the other hand, it makes the game tedious to marathon, but that's easily resolved with holding skip. There is also the Extend episode, which was required for the true end previously, but they moved it to the extras section since it was tedious to go through a bunch of old scenes in a route that had a number of flashbacks anyway.

Maybe because I've played a fair number of visual novels, but the twists that came up were somewhat expected compared to others. The story is tightly written, so any odd detail is bound to show up later in the story as rather important. Whether or not you enjoy it is up to the reader, but personally I enjoyed having to connect the information together and guess a little of what happens next.

The thing that impressed me the most was how they used the scientific principles fairly well. A common mistake of a lot of authors take is completely butchering physics principles. So other than the obvious artistic liberties they took, I was glad that the scientists and experiments they mentioned were at least valid. I learned a lot more than I expected about fire safety too.

I was not a big fan of how the options worked, since I wasn't too sure how high or low I needed to set the baseline value. The way it works is you set the relevant party's "trustworthiness" to 1-9 and that determines the action you take. Sometimes the option would give you a +1 to the person, and most of the times not much would change.
Upon finishing a route however, you gain the ability choose prechosen answers. Combined with the option to jump to the next relevant option input, it should make the game easier to 100% if you're that type of player.

This game is quite unique in its own, the story is amazing, and even though the amount of details put in for us can be hard to take since we all want to know "What is going to happen next" a little more than "What is going on", we still need a sufficient amount of detail and knowledge on the "What is going on" part for the next part to make sense. To have half of √B to be so filled with literally nothing but information and √D to be 50% about flashbacks can be dreadful, but my honest opinion is that it ain't as bad as the people make it out to be.

33386968.review:
[h1] A Great Idea...Which Requires A GREAT Deal of Patience [/h1]

[b] Summary

Root Double is NOT like most other visual novels. It is unusual and suspenseful. The game goes out of its way to be unusual...but that may or may not work for the average gamer. Still, the game has some amazing moments if you can have the patience to reach them.

Pros [/b]

+ A very interesting and suspenseful story
+ Great voice acting (in Japanese), music, and sound effects
+ A unique concept for a visual novel
+ High production values make this visual novel have a quality that is not present in many visual novels on Steam
+ Layers upon layers of plot exist in a VERY complicated and intricate system of twists and turns

[b] Cons [/b]

- The Enneagram concept is interesting but it really doesn't work as a system of making choices in a visual novel. The maker of the game chose to force the concept into the game in many places where a more conventional method of choice making would have made FAR more sense to the gamer.

- The game should have provided better hints as to the cause and consequences for choices. Sometimes, a choice should not result in a positive response from the people involved. (No response is okay sometimes, in other words.) Othertimes, the gamer must find the exact right way of making the given choice so that a positive effect occurs.

- The +1 and -1 signs that appear next to the Enneagram disappear FAR too fast given the interesting and suspenseful storyline. I have reloaded saves many times because by the time I am through reading a couple of sentences relating to the choice that was made, the +1 and -1 signs have disappeared. What this means is that the gamer must reload game saves until both the + and - results and the text results from the choice are all written down in some kind of document the gamer must use to determine what the best course of action really is.

- The translation is off in places. In one place, Yuuri says "hai", which means "yes". The game translates "hai" as "no", which ends up being confusing for people that don't have at least a very small vocabulary of the spoken Japanese language. Overall, the translation is good, but this novel could use a bit of polishing in the translation.

[b] Debatable [/b]

? So many visual novels have many good endings. It would not have been hard for the game maker to put more than two good endings into the game. But the game maker decided to put a great deal of effort into long and detailed bad endings. This may or may not work for you as a gamer.

? This game has a great many choices that the gamer must make. And the effects of those choices may not be felt for several hours of gameplay. The effects of most of the choices in the game are cumulative. This is why I said that the gamer should take detailed notes as the game progresses. The gamer is expected to keep track of the cumulative effect of the many choices in the game if the gamer wants to see the best ending of the game without the use of a guide (and a few do exist in the Steam forums).

? The game will have flashbacks within flashbacks while a VERY little time is passing in the real plot of the visual novel. This gets VERY tedious. You WILL need a great deal of patience to get through the flashbacks. They start in the B section of the novel, and they will drag on and on in the D section of the novel. By the time you are reading the D section of the novel, however, you will understand why the flashbacks are an integral part of the story. At that time (hopefully) you won't mind the flashbacks so much. But until then...plan on waiting a while.

[b] My suggestions [/b]

1) Buy the game on sale. While the visual novel has a high level of quality, the concept for the game's choice mechanism is a bit rough around the edges. The choice mechanism WILL make sense, but not until LONG after the gamer has had to make dozens of choices using that mechanism. Not all gamers have patience for that sort of thing.
 
2) Play the game for a while without using a guide from the Steam forums. Try to get a feel for what the game maker wanted the gamer to experience. It's an interesting thought...but that thought could have been implemented MUCH better for a MUCH more satisfying effect. And that leads me to my next suggestion.

3) Once you get one of the endings that tells you that character XYZ doesn't like the main character enough - OR - you start to get frustrated with the number of times you get the "game over" screen, start the game over and follow one of the Steam forum guides. There are different guides available for different play styles.

[b] Conclusion [/b]

Root Double is worth your time...particularly when you know what you are getting into ahead of time. Put the game on your wishlist until the game goes on sale.

[b] Tips [/b]

1 - Do not expect that playing through the Root A part of the game is enough to get the good ending of the Root A part of the game. While Root A is meant to be played first, Root B completion is required to get the good ending of Root A. If Root B was not nearly as tedious with all the flashbacks, I would consider telling you to play it first. Perhaps that is why the developer of the game allows the user to pick which one to play first--it really is a choice for you to make.

That said, [spoiler] Save the game in Root A where Ena is holding a gun and Ujita and Jun are questioning whether or not Ena should even be carrying the gun. This is where you will need to pick up Root A after completing Root B. [/spoiler]

2 - I have read that the xtend episode can be unlocked with the good end or the true (grand) end. I could only unlock xtend with the true end. And once I started playing xtend, I knew why. Therefore...

[spoiler]
Save the game once the Partner SSS choice comes up and DO NOT save over that game save. That is when Natsuhiko and Watase finally decide to join forces in the Root D part of the game.
[/spoiler]

33148032.review:
Root Double is an absolutely exceptional visual novel. It's an amazing mystery and thriller story. The characters are all great, distinct and their voiceovers are very well done. It explores lots of interesting themes and there is an amazing attention to detail in every regard. There is a lot of fictional (supernatural) science involved but every part of it is very well thought out and explained thoroughly which makes it very believable and plausible.

I'm quite new to the world of visual novels. This is my fourth VN and so far I've read a couple of the best ones (Steins;Gate, Steins;Gate 0 and The Devil on G String) and I thought there were always some plot holes, inconsistencies or fairly unreasonable dei ex machina in all of them. But not in Root Double. The story is almost perfect and I don't think there are any unreasonable elements; everything has a reasonable explanation and subtle hints are present from the very beginning that can prod you to make theories about parts of this vast mystery before the truth is revealed.

I have very few criticisms for Root Double. The story can drag a bit in some parts and suffers from overexposition, but I found the premise, characters and world engaging enough to enjoy those parts as well. Also, the choice system can be confusing and sometimes make the result of your choice the exact opposite of what you intended. It can take a lot of trial and error, time or the help of guides until you can reach the true ending.

But it's so very worth it. I've enjoyed every moment spent playing Root Double immensely.

32974250.review:
For thousands of years, humans have created and passed down handcrafted stories through generations. If you are unfamiliar with the visual novel genre, there are some things you should know going in:

1) Don't expect it to be a traditional "game" in that you can act upon the "in-game world" - you cannot. 
2) Don't expect to be able to impact the "game" much at all - everything in visual novels are completely scripted.
3) Visual novels should be played for the thorough enjoyment of both the story as well as the entire experience.

A visual novel is basically a regular novel, but on steroids. I've always loved reading, and perhaps some of the most incredible stories I have ever read have been visual novels due to the additional effects such as backgrounds, character artwork, sound effects, and most importantly... the soundtrack, which can drastically impact the mood and really creates the emotional atmosphere of the story as well as empathy towards the characters.

Some of the best stories I've ever experienced were products of Japanese creators. Although many people might associate anime and visual novels with "sex" because, let's face it, they 'can' be used for those purposes, that's just really one extreme. The reality is that anime, and in this case visual novels, are just another platform, another medium, for delivering some of the greatest stories ever written to the hearts and minds of people everywhere.

With that said... let's get to the VN itself: [b]Root Double -Before Crime * After Days[/b].

As mentioned in other reviews, [b]Root Double[/b] was produced by Takumi Nakazawa, the creator of the Infinity Series. Ever 17 in particular is critically acclaimed as one of the greatest visual novels ever written. In Root Double, Nakazawa utilizes a lot of the same elements from Ever 17, but the way he applies them is entirely original and unique, much different from its predecessor. Both of them, however, are outstanding productions and well worth the experiences which in my opinion will never be forgotten.

Root Double belongs to the “trapped” genre of visual novels, whereby the characters in the story find themselves stuck in some type of sticky situation and need to find their way out usually before disaster strikes, ending in most of their deaths. The novel consists of four routes: √A (after), √B (before), √C (current – unlocked after the first two routes are completed), and √D (double – unlocked once all routes are completed). Although the first two routes are both available from the start, they should [b]absolutely[/b] be played in chronological order. Each arc is told from a different perspective or viewpoint.

There are 39 different endings total throughout the four arcs, most of them bad, and they are almost all related to a certain “theme”.

√A is the question arc, whereby the story poses a lot of questions to the reader as it progresses and everything seems unclear, or a mystery. Having a question arc where things don’t necessarily all add up  dramatically increases the suspense of the story and greatly succeeds in building tension! While I was playing through √A, I wasn’t sure what was happening or why, but I was frantically trying to figure it out on the fly before the novel beat me to the explanations (saved for the later arcs). The story itself is very exciting and filled with drama, as lives are at stake and the threat of death is constantly looming at every step from multiple different outlets, whether it be the setting itself or even other characters! Multiple times throughout I had to pause and sit back and take a break because my heart was racing so fast from the tension and suspense. And while you’re trying to figure out what’s really going on, the game decides to fuck you over completely and turn in a completely unexpected direction. The plot twists were outstanding! At the end of the first arc, you’re left with a feeling of helplessness and confusion, but more importantly thinking “WHAT THE FUCK WAS THAT THAT WAS FUCKING AWESOME”. Completely mind-blowing. The first arc has 17 bad endings, one good ending, and one normal ending: I’d recommend definitely playing through both the normal and good endings (in that order) if nothing else. Both endings give different clues as to what might be occurring, and even some of the bad endings include helpful hints into the plot, as in learning more about other characters that you might not be interacting with in the two main endings. You might be thinking at this point… “Yeah, there’s a thrilling story that’s really cool, but does it all make sense?” And yes, it’s extremely easy to throw a bunch of crazy unrelated shit together and call it a story. But EVERYTHING in Root Double has a purpose, and it ALL ties together, as you’ll find out. Every single question you might have from √A and even in other arcs will be explained.

√B is the answer arc, whereby a lot of the confusion of the previous arc is cleared up. THIS BY NO MEANS EXPLAINS EVERYTHING, as even after √B is complete, a lot is left unexplained. Rather… it gives a lot of insight into the background of some of the characters and why certain events may have occurred. √B changes the perspective to a different main character that also is a part of the events that take place in √A. And honestly, I’d 100% consider the perspective of √B as the “main character” over Watase even though both of their perspectives are crucial to the plot: the story as a whole is more about the perspective of character √B. I really enjoyed the execution of √B with the story flipping back and forth between points in time both before and during the disaster – it helped build a lot of the tension and led towards one of the biggest reveals of the arc that I ended up shockingly figuring out myself a few minutes before it was presented. And yet even after the arc is completed, the story gets even better and saves some of the most shocking twists for √D.

√C basically merges the perspectives of the first two arcs and summarizes everything that has happened to that point – there aren’t any choices, but this arc is extremely helpful as a refresher and puts together some things you might not have thought about!

If you thought the first three arcs were good, you’ll be extremely unprepared for √D. Everything you previously thought was a lie (actually just very well masked) and the deception that is revealed is absolutely mind-blowing. In √D, the story ties together every single little thing and leaves no loose ends. There are even plot twists to the plot twists! And the best part… everything will make sense and fit together snugly like a jigsaw puzzle. There are no missing pieces, no blank spaces at the end. √D allows for the most user interaction into the outcome of the story out of all the arcs, and I’d strongly advise you to go through as many different endings as you possibly can.

I don’t want to give away too much about √D since it was my favorite part of the game, but the amount of information it gives regarding every single character in the novel is insane and the characters themselves develop strongly through learning about each other as you learn about them at the same time.

I cried during √D. A lot. And not just at the endings, a lot of which were pretty heartwrenching. It hit me right in the feels and drew me in so much closer emotionally, which I really, really enjoyed. The emotional impact Root Double had on me as a whole can only be described by playing the game for yourselves.

Root Double, from beginning to end, was an incredible journey that I want to etch into my memory forever. It truly is a masterpiece.

[b][u]Plot[/u][/b]
I personally loved the setting of the story and the development of the plot throughout the entire novel. Although some twists were “predictable” per se, they had to be deduced through the information given throughout the story and weren’t completely apparent. What I loved most about the plot, however, (continued in comments)

32741802.review:
Got this game in Humble Bundle's Sekai Project. Well worth its price here though (discount or not). 

Overall:

This is the first visual novel I have played. And honestly, it has a better story then all the other games I have ever played. This surprised me. The long Campaign is over 50 hours with 30 hours of  content. Player choice does affect the world significantly, as this has 39 endings, mostly bad. Sometimes, in order to make the right choice the main character needed to have low confidence in himself, which is something I have personally never seen in any video game before. Solid background score and sound design.

Routes:

Both routes are very good (Root A and Root B) and there is some content generated based on what endings you get. Root B may seem boring, but picks up steam significantly in the last third of the game, and its finale (just pre and post credits) will explain the events in the start of Root A. 

Characters:
8 of the 9 characters you interact with are amazing with great voice acting backing up a very rich backstory, 1 (lets call them: bonde ninja) is pretty annoying. Both protagonists are very well developed as well. 

Lore: 
Possibly has the least plot holes I have seen in any work. I am not joking, on my first playthrough, I noticed and predicted plot events based on information I got, while people may say that this makes the game "predictable", no its not, its that nothing feels like an ass pull, and you feel rewarded when you see your prediction become true or realize that you misunderstood that information(remember this game allows the main character to have low confidence in his abilities). World of Root Double has solid foundations and does not rely on Deus ex Machina.

32457909.review:
There are several other good reviews that I definitely agree with, so I will try to express some things that have not already been said while confirming previous observations. Mostly spoiler free aside from the structure of the game below and my impressions of the routes in terms of pacing, detail, etc. Please don't take this as a negative review, I just want to point out some things I feel people should know so they can finish the game happily, unlike the couple of negative reviews from people who have not scratched the surface of what Root Double has to offer...

Root Double is a story told from multiple perspectives that conjoin to create one full story. 
√A: fast paced story of the events inside LABO, a deteriorating research facility
√B: A slower paced, informational explanation of the context of the city, the facility, and some key worldbuilding points
√C: (Unlocked after both √A and √B) A recap/addition to the previous events
√D: (Unlocked after √C) The final route where everything gets tied together
Extend Episodes: More details to tie loose ends (I have not started these yet and will not offer my opinion of them for this reason)

Here are the issues I had while playing the game:
- After an exciting and clean-cut √A, √B is packed with a lot of fluff that could've been summed up in half the time. That said, you do get a lot of scenes that strengthen your feelings towards the characters. 
- √B has a LOT of exposition. A TON of pseudo-science technobabble. It is important to the story but the explanations really shouldn't be told in the form of literal classroom lessons. It breaks the flow of the game considerably, and for this reason, among others, I would not play √B first. 
- √D is told almost entirely in flashbacks of things you've already seen. It drags. A lot. 
- Some of the plot points are easily guessable right off the bat, and some are totally out of left field. At points the characters would say something like "Oh! Now I get it!" regarding something that I had assumed to be true an hour ago. Other times, they'd assume something and I'd have to keep pressing forward with the dialogue to even understand what they meant. But it all does click after that, so not a big issue. 

The game could've been cut considerably, and I do wish they slowed down a bit with the exposition and backstory. Every character has their chance to tell their story, which is nice, but it dampens the drama because the game is so saturated with it. I found myself caring less about each successive trauma-riddled past and more impatient for the game to get to the point of the incident. 

WITH THAT SAID, everything is worth it. The game is a meticulously crafted tale. Every tiny detail fits together like the world's most wordy jigsaw puzzle. They really left no stone unturned. Every word each character says, every action, they are all hand picked carefully to create the tale. The characters are all likable, understandable, and act in realistic ways. If you're on the store page for Root Double, it's because you like suspense/mystery games and are probably interested in visual novels. Maybe you even have a couple Infinity series games under your belt like I do. In this case, it's a no brainer. In fact, I would encourage anyone even mildly curious to buy this game. 

At the time of this writing, Humble Bundle has a bundle with this game and a couple other visual novel titles for $12. Absolutely pick it up.

32403791.review:
[h1] 馆[/h1]
馆”这类的作品一直都是日本人的最爱，不管从小说到动画还是到黄油。这类的作品都会成为各个剧本家、小说家竞相发挥自己才能的舞台。
这种限定了故事舞台的作品，对剧本家笔力的考验更大。这种游戏没有所谓的日常，即没法通过日常进行剧情过渡。因为故事舞台的限制他可能是全程压抑的，更加侧重于人性，登场角色心理活动的描写，个人独白等等，通过这些来推进剧情。
所以，“馆”这种题材对于剧本家把握剧情的节奏，走向，力度都有更高的要求。比如翠之海，散乱的剧本构成是其成功的重要原因，通过切割剧本构成来达到分段式将各条线压抑的气氛松弛有度表达出来。当然笔力强的比如田中在神树之馆中单凭笔力就能让玩家达到身临其境的感觉，其实我是挺想说CROSS+CHANNEL严格意义上它并不属于“馆”。
接着上面来说，“馆”为何为“馆”。所谓的“馆”其实是一种枷锁，牢笼，借用钱钟书先生的一句话“城里的人想出去 城外的人想进来”。“馆”是外人所探寻之物，也是里面的人所想冲破的牢笼。
[h1] 舞台[/h1]
引申到故事上演的舞台也是如此，舞台决定上演的物语是残酷还是温暖。比如KID的LOOP三部曲，龙骑士07的寒蝉，海猫系列、中泽工的秘密游戏系列、等等这类游戏并不限于“馆”但是他们同样执着与故事的舞台，这些舞台同样被严加限定，不管是明写还是暗指都被赋予深刻的含义。
所谓开篇容易结尾难，结尾还得用游戏。
随笔写下这些是因为这部游戏的舞台和ever17很像，也想起来以前打过的end sleep，总之还是很有趣的游戏。

Да история хороша, но у истории есть еще аспекты, антураж, персонажи, повествование, да просто здравый смысл и еще многое. И вот в этих аспектах игра лажает по полной. Всю игру вас кидает на те же сцены, те же мотивы и те же действия. Да они раскрываются под другим углом, да часть из них нужна чтобы раскрыть персонажей и мотивы. Это слишком явная проблема, можно списать идиотский слайс в Before, можно простить рояли на которых играет бог из машины, можно забить на не стыковки в сценарии и на про♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ную в некоторых моментах логику. Можно даже простить идиотскую true концовку и странное управление. Но не это. Ну нельзя всю историю забивать повторением этой же истории. Мы двигаемся на шаг вперед, а потом смотрим что было два шага назад. Отличная история, дурная подача. Были бы оценки я бы залепил 3\5, но тут только рек. или не рек. 32228047.review:
Piégés à l'intérieur d'un centre de recherche connu sous le nom de LABO, avec un désastre imminent planant sur eux, sans aucune explication du pourquoi et comment. Les survivants doivent s'échapper de cet enfer dans un laps de temps donné...

[i]Root Double -Before Crime * After Days- Xtend Edition[/i] est un VN très bien narré et certainement l'un des meilleurs VNs disponibles à ce jour sur Steam. Celui-ci dispose d'un très bon prologue, d'une intrigue palpitante, d'un bon développement sur les personnages et de plus la route finale est à en couper le souffle ! C'est définitivement le Visual Novel dont l'histoire ne doit pas être ratée. 

Pour une meilleure expérience, il vous est fortement conseillé de commencer par la route After avant de passer par Before. 

Dans un premier temps, vous êtes dans la peau de Watase Kasasagi, capitaine d'une équipe de sauvetage travaillant pour "Sirius". Il se réveillera dans cet enfer avec une amnésie, ne sachant plus qui il est et pourquoi il se retrouve dans cette situation. Cette route met en place l'histoire, beaucoup de problèmes et questions se succèderont, ne laissant ainsi aucun répis aux lecteurs.

Dans un second temps, la route Before répondra à toutes les questions que vous vous poserez lors de la lecture de After. Cette fois-ci, vous suivrez Natsuhiko Tenkawa, un simple étudiant qui devra revivre les évènements passés durant les 6 derniers jours pour découvrir la vérité derrière ce désastre. Pour ma part, c'est la route la plus ennuyante et lente de tous... j'ai été super content de l'avoir fini le plus vite possible.

Une chose est sûre, les survivants devront se serrer les coudes entre eux pour pouvoir survivre.

Au niveau du gameplay, on a ici quelque chose de complètement différent comparée aux autres VNs. La plupart des VNs nous limitent à de simples sélections de choix, Root Double joue sur le niveau de confiance que l'on a envers les personnages appelé Senses Sympathy System. Le seul point commun entre ces deux gameplays, un mauvais choix est c'est le Bad Ending assuré, assez frustant personellement.

Pour ce qui est de la bande sonore, je n'ai rien à reprocher, extrêmement parfaite du début à la fin et quand il faut. Je ne m'ennuie jamais à les écouter en boucle.

31453201.review:
If I had to describe this VN in simple words it would be: Mind Blowing
It's been a while since I played a VN as interesting and intense as the Zero Escape series and Danganronpa although it does have some pacing issues regarding the overall story.
This VN has 2 different prespectives in other words it has 2 MCs. The MC of Root A Watase and the MC of Root B Natsuhiko. The choices you make are based on a trust system using a diagram that the game has a tutorial for before any choices can be made.
Here are my simple thoughts on each Root (route):

Root A: Amazing and very action packed filled with suspense and doubt.
Root B: 80% highscool slice of life, world building, and character development for characters we didn't even know well that I felt like quitting so many times but endured it all for what's to come and something finally happen in the 20% that is left of the route.
Root C: Short recap of Root A from a different prespective that it answers some of the mysteries.
Root D: Continuation of Root A where the truth is finally shown and things are connected.
Xtend Episode: Bonus where we can find out more about the main characters and some unanswered questions in the main game.

p.s. I dislike the Root B MC and really like the Root A MC. Watase FTW!

31384714.review:
Foreword: You're gonna find people who'll debate this, but *play ROOT AFTER FIRST.* Root A stars a character who starts with amnesia, so it does well to have the character mirror the player in learning about the setting of the story. Plus it gets into the action immediately, compared to B which has a very gradual bulidup.

Playtime:  ~27 hours is the amount of time it took for me to finish the game, while playing through any bad/alternative endings I happened to run into. (around 5 to 7 of them)

Main review: Very well might be my favorite visual novel of all time. Huge length, fully voice acted, genuine "gamefeel" things implemented like screen shake, ambient sounds, falling ember particle effects, and heat haze that sell the setting of a blazing nuclear research facillity. 

Twists and story beats are handled elegantly, most notably with a very major reveal done 20 minutes in because the writers knew that if they used it as a plot twist later on it would feel like utterly unpredictable BS. Sorta like how if you're gonna have a "it was all a dream" twist, you damn well better not end your story with it.

A great majority of other plot details and reveals are hinted at throughout, which both lends the game well to writing theories and speculation down, and to allowing you to think back and say "oh, *THATS* why that occured back then!" Every character feels unique and serves an important purpose, with their own motivations and justifiable reasonings for their actions. I ended up hand writing a full 2 sided paper of my current theories while I was playing through.


Overall, Root Double tonally and conceptually most resembles other visual novels like 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors or other works directed by Kotaro Uchikoshi, so if you liked the Zero Escape series or generally near future Sci-fi suspense stories, then this game is most likely right up your alley.

30999584.review:

30908552.review:
Memories are interesting things. They keep us tethered to the word around us, but are surprisingly fragile and can shatter in a mere instant. Not to mention that they are prone to distortion or outright fabrication. Yet they are the most important way that you can connect with someone and in, a way, give your own existance worth and meaning. While not strictly making that case until a scene at the tailend of the VN, it's a common theme in Root Double.

The plot of Root Double is a bit hard to describe because it involves the convergence of two stories. The first story is that of Watase, a rescue worker that has developed amnesia. The catch is that as a result of this amnesia, he's been thrown into a situation seemingly of the explosion of a nuclear reactor, radiation seems to keep going up, and he needs to figure out a way for him and everyone under his care (including multiple civilians, a worker at the lab, and his two subordinates). This ends up proving more complicated than he could possibly imagine as bodies start to pile up.

The other story is that of Natsuhiko, an esper (while not technical accurate it's a decent colloquial description), that is supposedly powerful but is unable for his abilities to manifest. While this is certainly closer to the typical VN experience, as it were, I feel that the author handles it effectively and deftly. All the characters are interesting and likable and there is clearly enough mystery going on that I was far too immersed in the characters and story to be particularly upset that it isn'tthe most original thing in the world.

The music and visuals are quite good and compliment the story effectively as well.

Overall I could be more specific about certain aspects but I really think this game is stronger going in as blind as possible. You're in for a treat- this is easily the best $15 I've spent on Steam in a long time.

30848788.review:
[h1]Root Double –Before Crime * After Days- Xtend Edition[/h1]

Histoire visuelle qui entre directement dans mon top 3. Vous incarnez à tour de rôle Watase, le capitaine d’une équipe de sauvetage qui souffre d’amnésie et Natsuhiko un étudiant. Piégés dans un centre de recherche sur le nucléaire appelé « LABO » avec 7 autres personnages ils vont luter pour leur survie et lever progressivement le voile sur tous les mystères qui les entourent.

L’histoire est divisée en 4 parties et si vous voulez profiter pleinement de l’expérience commencez par « After ». Ce premier épisode va vous plonger directement dans le bain, vous serez sous tension du début à la fin tel un héro sans ses souvenirs qui ne comprend pas tout ce qui se passe mais lutte pour sa survie et celle des autres. La suite « before » fait retomber la pression et vous ramène a un peu plus de légèreté en vous faisant revivre les jours qui précèdent l’incident. C’est l’occasion de vous apportez les premières réponses avant de vous replonger dans ce « LABO » avec un regard neuf. 
J’ai lu pas mal de critiques qui disent que « After » est excellent mais que la suite est moins bonne, personnellement je pense qu’il faut juger l’œuvre dans sa globalité pour vraiment en apprécier la qualité. A part quelques petites longueurs et répétitions, tout est parfaitement calculé, les réponses vous sont dévoilées au compte goutte avec de nouvelles questions, tout s’imbrique à merveille et le suspens est maintenu jusqu’à la fin. 

Les auteurs ont vraiment pris le temps de bien nous plonger dans la tête des personnages, il y a beaucoup de flashback, certains verrons çà comme des longueurs, je trouve qu’au contraire çà permet de bien les comprendre et apprendre à tous les apprécier. 

L’histoire est intelligente, même si çà reste de la fiction on sent qu’il y a eu un vrai travail de recherche en amont et on apprend des choses, çà vaut le coup de lire les Tips. Moi qui m’intéresse beaucoup aux neurosciences j’ai vraiment adoré.

Les graphismes sont magnifiques, j’ai battu mon record de screenshot et la musique est également parfaite pour coller avec l’ambiance.

Niveau gameplay, le jeu est original, il nous propose un système de choix basé sur notre ressenti à propos des personnages, en quelque sorte si on leur fait confiance ou pas. Au début c’est un peu déstabilisant, on sait pas trop comment le régler mais on se rend vite compte que mettre 0 ou 1 change pas grand chose et on se restreint vite à 2 ou 3 positions. Certaines fins ne sont pas évidentes à trouver mais une fois que vous aurez eu une fois la bonne fin les différentes possibilités pour chaque choix vous sont données. 

 [h1]En conclusion : [/h1]
« Root Double –Before Crime * After Days » est une des meilleures histoires visuelles que j’ai lu jusqu’ici. Passionnante, extrêmement bien écrite, construite et illustrée, à part quelques petites longueurs je ne lui trouve aucun défaut. Sans aucun doute un incontournable du genre que je recommande à tous les lecteurs ! 

[b]Bilan : 9.7/10[/b]

[h1]English summary : [/h1]
« Root Double –Before Crime * After Days » is one of the best visual novel i ever read. Exciting, extremely well-written story, nice art and endearing characters ; except for few lenghty passages, this game is perfect. Without any doubt, a must-have that i highly recommend !

[h1] Hanging onto your memory will you recover the truth? [/h1]

Two groups connected by fate seeking escape. On one side rescue worker with strong will to save lives or so he believes. On the other is a high-schooler with talent towards telepathy. All around sudden disaster, crushing your peaceful days on Rokumei. Your mind, your reality and past, everything is unstable, crumbling. That’s how it starts. There is no clear answer. Just a hope to survive another hour through fire, radiation and much more inside LABO.


Best things in Root Double are bound by decision system. SSS is a complex thing, sort of trust mechanism (also in your past), even slightest choice can lead to long consequence, if person distrust you or the other way around. There is no indication though that hero will act as you want. There are no meaningless decisions, almost all can change mood and create threat. Discovering good end is difficult because of that. Each section: After, Before and more, to reach final +40 hours is a minimum, many relationships and feelings along the way, from many point of views.


Root Double is a bit repetitive at times with ost, revisiting past and occasional re-reading same events. Some cool action scenes are also unrealistic. DESPITE all that though you can't complain. Nothing seems to be underdeveloped. Besides It misses just a little to be incredible VN, somewhere in the flow of the story, when After route ends less decisions appears. Kazami <3

29623662.review:
So let me start off by saying that I'm a bit biased when it comes to these types of visual novels. I don't play them as much as I used to anymore, but this one was one that I just had to pick up when I heard about it and saw the kickstarter for it.
In short, it's one of those visual novels where there are 9 or so different people trapped in a place that's locked down for a certain number of hours, and they have to escape within a certain amount of time or else they die and etc. 

But there is so much more to it than that, I tell you hwut.

Like I said I'm a bit of a sucker for these types of games, but depending on what kinds of stories and scenarios and cliches you like/are okay with, you may like this game as much as me, or you might just find many of the tropes and cliches kind of annoying. This is an anime visual novel, so the typical anime tropes will be here. I do find some of them kind of annoying, but it doesn't really get in the way of the good parts of the whole thing overall, in my opinion.

I've heard that people thought that this game starts off slow, or it had a good premise but they feel if goes too slowly or there's not a good payoff in the end? And to that I say that it's somewhat true, but I believe the payoff is well worth it in the end. 
It has good characters, a good story, good plot, good twists.. I couldn't be happier. Like I said in my little review of the 3rd Zero Escape game, this is the type of game where I do look back on when I first played it and didn't know anything about the story or characters or all that, and I wish I could go back and replay it without knowing anything. 

So without rambling too much about nothing, I do recommend this game if you like visual novels. It was even recommended by the guy who made/wrote the 999/Zero Escape games, so that's basically all you need to know if it's good or not!! Definitely recommend.
